CVE-2021-44228
(10.0 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 97.56%

updated 2024-02-05T20:54:55

3 posts

# Summary Log4j versions prior to 2.16.0 are subject to a remote code execution vulnerability via the ldap JNDI parser. As per [Apache's Log4j security guide](https://logging.apache.org/log4j/2.x/security.html): Apache Log4j2 <=2.14.1 JNDI features used in configuration, log messages, and parameters do not protect against attacker controlled LDAP and other JNDI related endpoints. An attacker who

##
simontsui at 2024-02-22T13:28:07.654Z ##

Uptycs reported on a new campaign by the Chinese cybercriminal group "8220 Gang" from May 2023 to February 2024, leveraging Log4Shell CVE-2021-44228 (10.0 critical, 10 December 2021 by Apache, RCE in Log4j 2) and CVE-2022-26134 (9.8 critical, 03 June 2022 by Atlassian, RCE in Confluence) for initial access. They exploit Windows and Linux platforms for cryptomining. Attack chain and IOC provided.

##

CVE-2022-26134
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 97.53%

updated 2023-01-27T05:03:24

3 posts

In affected versions of Confluence Server and Data Center, an OGNL injection vulnerability exists that would allow an unauthenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code on a Confluence Server or Data Center instance. The affected versions are from 1.3.0 before 7.4.17, from 7.13.0 before 7.13.7, from 7.14.0 before 7.14.3, from 7.15.0 before 7.15.2, from 7.16.0 before 7.16.4, from 7.17.0 before 7.17

simontsui at 2024-02-22T13:28:07.654Z ##

Uptycs reported on a new campaign by the Chinese cybercriminal group "8220 Gang" from May 2023 to February 2024, leveraging Log4Shell CVE-2021-44228 (10.0 critical, 10 December 2021 by Apache, RCE in Log4j 2) and CVE-2022-26134 (9.8 critical, 03 June 2022 by Atlassian, RCE in Confluence) for initial access. They exploit Windows and Linux platforms for cryptomining. Attack chain and IOC provided.
ð https://www.uptycs.com/blog/8220-gang-cryptomining-cloud-based-infrastructure-cyber-threat

#cybercrime #threatintel #8220Gang #cryptomining #cryptojacking #IOC

##

CVE-2017-11882
(7.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 97.44%

updated 2021-03-16T17:21:45.660000

1 posts

Microsoft Office 2007 Service Pack 3, Microsoft Office 2010 Service Pack 2, Microsoft Office 2013 Service Pack 1, and Microsoft Office 2016 allow an attacker to run arbitrary code in the context of the current user by failing to properly handle objects in memory, aka "Microsoft Office Memory Corruption Vulnerability". This CVE ID is unique from CVE-2017-11884.

ptesarik@fosstodon.org at 2024-02-29T13:55:17.000Z ##

Have you noticed that all public CNAs assign only negative numbers (like CVE-2017-5754)? So, what's with the positive CVE numbers (CVE+2024+xxxx)? They are assigned by secret CNAs! To hide even the fact there are any such CNAs, the positive-number CVEs must never be published.

Um, this conspiracy theory is even more stupid than flat Earth. So it may catch upâ¦

##
ptesarik@fosstodon.org at 2024-02-29T13:55:17.000Z ##

Have you noticed that all public CNAs assign only negative numbers (like CVE-2017-5754)? So, what's with the positive CVE numbers (CVE+2024+xxxx)? They are assigned by secret CNAs! To hide even the fact there are any such CNAs, the positive-number CVEs must never be published.

Um, this conspiracy theory is even more stupid than flat Earth. So it may catch upâ¦

##

CVE-2023-42793
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 97.34%

updated 2023-11-06T05:02:06

2 posts

In JetBrains TeamCity before 2023.05.4 authentication bypass leading to RCE on TeamCity Server was possible

5 repos

https://github.com/LeHeron/TC_test

https://github.com/Zenmovie/CVE-2023-42793

https://github.com/StanleyJobsonAU/GhostTown

https://github.com/H454NSec/CVE-2023-42793

https://github.com/johnossawy/CVE-2023-42793_POC

simontsui at 2024-03-05T16:42:41.230Z ##

Why you should care about the new JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2024-27198 (9.8 critical):

  • On 18 October 2023, Microsoft observed North Korean state-sponsored APTs Diamond Sleet (aka Lazarus Group, publicly attributed to 110 Research Center 3rd Technical Surveillance Bureau of Reconnaissance General Bureau by the US Government) and Onyx Sleet (aka Andariel, also publicly attributed to RGB by the US Government) exploiting a similar JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2023-42793.
  • On 13 December 2023, CISA published a cybersecurity advisory reporting that the Russian state-sponsored APT29 (Cozy Bear, publicly attributed to Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the USG) was mass-exploiting CVE-2023-42793 since September 2023.
  • From public disclosure to proof of concept was 6 days. Exploitation was within 7 days after that (KEV Catalog in 15 days). Nation-state abuse within 12-22 days of public disclosure.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-05T16:42:41.000Z ##

Why you should care about the new JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2024-27198 (9.8 critical):

  • On 18 October 2023, Microsoft observed North Korean state-sponsored APTs Diamond Sleet (aka Lazarus Group, publicly attributed to 110 Research Center 3rd Technical Surveillance Bureau of Reconnaissance General Bureau by the US Government) and Onyx Sleet (aka Andariel, also publicly attributed to RGB by the US Government) exploiting a similar JetBrains TeamCity authentication bypass vulnerability CVE-2023-42793.
  • On 13 December 2023, CISA published a cybersecurity advisory reporting that the Russian state-sponsored APT29 (Cozy Bear, publicly attributed to Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) by the USG) was mass-exploiting CVE-2023-42793 since September 2023.
  • From public disclosure to proof of concept was 6 days. Exploitation was within 7 days after that (KEV Catalog in 15 days). Nation-state abuse within 12-22 days of public disclosure.

#JetBrains #TeamCity #vulnerability #securityadvisory #CVE_2024_27198 #CVE_2024_27199 #Rapid7 #Poc #proofofconcept

##

CVE-2024-21887
(9.1 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 97.30%

updated 2024-01-22T18:31:16

12 posts

A command injection vulnerability in web components of Ivanti Connect Secure (9.x, 22.x) and Ivanti Policy Secure (9.x, 22.x) allows an authenticated administrator to send specially crafted requests and execute arbitrary commands on the appliance.

Nuclei template

13 repos

https://github.com/gobysec/Goby

https://github.com/Chocapikk/CVE-2024-21887

https://github.com/oways/ivanti-CVE-2024-21887

simontsui at 2024-03-02T01:23:46.663Z ##

TechCrunch: NSA confirmed that hackers exploiting flaws in Ivantiâs widely used enterprise VPN appliance have targeted organizations across the U.S. defense sector.
ð https://techcrunch.com/2024/03/01/nsa-says-its-tracking-ivanti-cyberattacks-as-hackers-hit-us-defense-sector/

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

##
0xThiebaut at 2024-03-01T14:51:22.738Z ##

We're still discovering further ramifications to #Ivanti's #PulseSecure vulnerabilities (#CVE_2023_46805 & #CVE_2024_21887). In February, we identified two new backdoors: #SparkCockpit & #SparkTar. Both backdoors employ selective interception of TLS communication, offer multiple degrees of persistence and access possibilities into the victim network (e.g., traffic tunneling through SOCKS proxy).

ð Analysis & detection rules at https://blog.nviso.eu/2024/03/01/covert-tls-n-day-backdoors-sparkcockpit-sparktar/

The findings of our investigation have been independently corroborated by the research performed by Mandiant and have partially been observed by Fortinet.

#threatintel #forensics #reverseengineering

##
simontsui at 2024-02-29T18:13:43.608Z ##

Hot off the press! CISA along with FBI, MS-ISAC, Australia ASD ACSC, NCSC-UK, NCSC-NZ, Canadian Centre for Cyber Security and CERT NZ release joint cybersecurity advisory Threat Actors Exploit Multiple Vulnerabilities in Ivanti Connect Secure and Policy Secure Gateways. It includes TTPs, IOCs, and detection methods to help network defenders mitigate risk.
ð https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060b

Of particular concern, the authoring organizations and industry partners have determined that cyber threat actors are able to deceive Ivantiâs internal and external Integrity Checker Tool (ICT), resulting in a failure to detect compromise.

During multiple incident response engagements associated with this activity, CISA identified that Ivantiâs internal and previous external ICT failed to detect compromise. In addition, CISA has conducted independent research in a lab environment validating that the Ivanti ICT is not sufficient to detect compromise and that a cyber threat actor may be able to gain root-level persistence despite issuing factory resets.

The authoring organizations strongly urge all organizations to consider the significant risk of adversary access to, and persistence on, Ivanti Connect Secure and Ivanti Policy Secure gateways when determining whether to continue operating these devices in an enterprise environment.

cc: @campuscodi @briankrebs @deepthoughts10 @serghei @selenalarson @DaveMWilburn

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

##
simontsui at 2024-02-28T21:15:54.019Z ##

This line from Mandiant's article stuck out to me: "In addition, we have seen the threat actor demonstrate a nuanced understanding of the appliance and their ability to subvert detection throughout this campaign."

The reason is because of the following:

The internal ICT is configured to run in two-hour intervals by default and is meant to be run in conjunction with continuous monitoring. Any malicious file system modifications made and reverted between the two-hour scan intervals would remain undetected by the ICT. When the activation and deactivation routines are performed tactfully in quick succession, it can minimize the risk of ICT detection by timing the activation routine to coincide precisely with the intended use of the BUSHWALK webshell.

This sentence also concerns me, giving me flashbacks to Eclypsium's article

An encrypted version of BUSHWALK is placed in a directory excluded by the integrity checker tool (ICT)

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024

##
simontsui at 2024-02-27T19:45:07.447Z ##

Ivanti has a related blog post regarding evolving threat actor tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs). These findings were identified in the ongoing analysis of the previously disclosed vulnerabilities affecting Ivanti Connect Secure, Policy Secure and ZTA gateways, and include potential persistence techniques.
ð https://www.ivanti.com/blog/enhanced-external-integrity-checking-tool-to-provide-additional-visibility-and-protection-for-customers-against-evolving-threat-actor-techniques-in-relation-to-previously-disclosed-vulnerabilities

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_21893 #CVE_2024_22024

##

CVE-2021-36380
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 97.17%

updated 2024-03-06T03:30:28

8 posts

Sunhillo SureLine before 8.7.0.1.1 allows Unauthenticated OS Command Injection via shell metacharacters in ipAddr or dnsAddr /cgi/networkDiag.cgi.

Nuclei template

simontsui at 2024-03-05T18:47:57.860Z ##

In tracking the origins of exploitation leading up to their KEV Catalog additions:

  • I previously informed the CISA Vulnerability Management Team of potential exploitation of CVE-2021-36380 as part of an IZ1H9 Mirai-based DDoS campaign reported by Fortinet on 09 October 2023. What they do with that information is up to them.
  • The Pixel Update Bulletin published 13 June 2023 included an announcement that read "Note: There are indications that CVE-2023-21237 may be under limited, targeted exploitation."

#CISA #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #eitw #activeexploitation #vulnerability #CVE_2023_21237 #CVE_2021_36380

##
simontsui at 2024-03-05T16:07:00.301Z ##

Hot off the press! CISA adds 2 vulnerabilities to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog.
ð https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/03/05/cisa-adds-two-known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog

  • CVE-2023-21237 (5.5 medium) Android Pixel Information Disclosure Vulnerability
  • CVE-2021-36380 (9.8 critical) Sunhillo SureLine OS Command Injection Vulnerablity

#CISA #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #eitw #activeexploitation #vulnerability #CVE_2023_21237 #CVE_2021_36380

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-05T18:47:57.000Z ##

In tracking the origins of exploitation leading up to their KEV Catalog additions:

  • I previously informed the CISA Vulnerability Management Team of potential exploitation of CVE-2021-36380 as part of an IZ1H9 Mirai-based DDoS campaign reported by Fortinet on 09 October 2023. What they do with that information is up to them.
  • The Pixel Update Bulletin published 13 June 2023 included an announcement that read "Note: There are indications that CVE-2023-21237 may be under limited, targeted exploitation."

#CISA #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #eitw #activeexploitation #vulnerability #CVE_2023_21237 #CVE_2021_36380

##

CVE-2023-46805
(8.2 HIGH)

EPSS: 96.27%

updated 2024-01-31T05:07:17

12 posts

An authentication bypass vulnerability in the web component of Ivanti ICS 9.x, 22.x and Ivanti Policy Secure allows a remote attacker to access restricted resources by bypassing control checks.

Nuclei template

9 repos

https://github.com/w2xim3/CVE-2023-46805

simontsui at 2024-03-02T01:23:46.663Z ##

TechCrunch: NSA confirmed that hackers exploiting flaws in Ivantiâs widely used enterprise VPN appliance have targeted organizations across the U.S. defense sector.
ð https://techcrunch.com/2024/03/01/nsa-says-its-tracking-ivanti-cyberattacks-as-hackers-hit-us-defense-sector/

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

##
0xThiebaut at 2024-03-01T14:51:22.738Z ##

We're still discovering further ramifications to #Ivanti's #PulseSecure vulnerabilities (#CVE_2023_46805 & #CVE_2024_21887). In February, we identified two new backdoors: #SparkCockpit & #SparkTar. Both backdoors employ selective interception of TLS communication, offer multiple degrees of persistence and access possibilities into the victim network (e.g., traffic tunneling through SOCKS proxy).

ð Analysis & detection rules at https://blog.nviso.eu/2024/03/01/covert-tls-n-day-backdoors-sparkcockpit-sparktar/

The findings of our investigation have been independently corroborated by the research performed by Mandiant and have partially been observed by Fortinet.

#threatintel #forensics #reverseengineering

##
simontsui at 2024-02-29T18:13:43.608Z ##

Hot off the press! CISA along with FBI, MS-ISAC, Australia ASD ACSC, NCSC-UK, NCSC-NZ, Canadian Centre for Cyber Security and CERT NZ release joint cybersecurity advisory Threat Actors Exploit Multiple Vulnerabilities in Ivanti Connect Secure and Policy Secure Gateways. It includes TTPs, IOCs, and detection methods to help network defenders mitigate risk.
ð https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060b

Of particular concern, the authoring organizations and industry partners have determined that cyber threat actors are able to deceive Ivantiâs internal and external Integrity Checker Tool (ICT), resulting in a failure to detect compromise.

During multiple incident response engagements associated with this activity, CISA identified that Ivantiâs internal and previous external ICT failed to detect compromise. In addition, CISA has conducted independent research in a lab environment validating that the Ivanti ICT is not sufficient to detect compromise and that a cyber threat actor may be able to gain root-level persistence despite issuing factory resets.

The authoring organizations strongly urge all organizations to consider the significant risk of adversary access to, and persistence on, Ivanti Connect Secure and Ivanti Policy Secure gateways when determining whether to continue operating these devices in an enterprise environment.

cc: @campuscodi @briankrebs @deepthoughts10 @serghei @selenalarson @DaveMWilburn

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

##
simontsui at 2024-02-28T21:15:54.019Z ##

This line from Mandiant's article stuck out to me: "In addition, we have seen the threat actor demonstrate a nuanced understanding of the appliance and their ability to subvert detection throughout this campaign."

The reason is because of the following:

The internal ICT is configured to run in two-hour intervals by default and is meant to be run in conjunction with continuous monitoring. Any malicious file system modifications made and reverted between the two-hour scan intervals would remain undetected by the ICT. When the activation and deactivation routines are performed tactfully in quick succession, it can minimize the risk of ICT detection by timing the activation routine to coincide precisely with the intended use of the BUSHWALK webshell.

This sentence also concerns me, giving me flashbacks to Eclypsium's article

An encrypted version of BUSHWALK is placed in a directory excluded by the integrity checker tool (ICT)

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024

##
simontsui at 2024-02-27T19:45:07.447Z ##

Ivanti has a related blog post regarding evolving threat actor tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs). These findings were identified in the ongoing analysis of the previously disclosed vulnerabilities affecting Ivanti Connect Secure, Policy Secure and ZTA gateways, and include potential persistence techniques.
ð https://www.ivanti.com/blog/enhanced-external-integrity-checking-tool-to-provide-additional-visibility-and-protection-for-customers-against-evolving-threat-actor-techniques-in-relation-to-previously-disclosed-vulnerabilities

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_21893 #CVE_2024_22024

CVE-2024-21893
(8.2 HIGH)

EPSS: 96.25%

updated 2024-02-09T05:11:32

2 posts

A server-side request forgery vulnerability in the SAML component of Ivanti Connect Secure (9.x, 22.x) and Ivanti Policy Secure (9.x, 22.x) and Ivanti Neurons for ZTA allows an attacker to access certain restricted resources without authentication.

##

CVE-2024-1709
(10.0 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 93.46%

updated 2024-02-23T02:00:01.867000

54 posts

ConnectWise ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by an Authentication Bypass Using an Alternate Path or Channel vulnerability, which may allow an attacker direct access to confidential information or critical systems.

Nuclei template

3 repos

https://github.com/W01fh4cker/ScreenConnect-AuthBypass-RCE

https://github.com/HussainFathy/CVE-2024-1709

https://github.com/tr1pl3ight/POCv2.0-for-CVE-2024-1709

H3liumb0y at 2024-03-05T09:16:48.983Z ##

"ð¨ ScreenConnect Exploits Unleash ToddleShark Malware by Kimsuky ð¨"

Kimsuky, the North Korean APT, leverages vulnerabilities in ScreenConnect (CVE-2024-1708 & CVE-2024-1709) to deploy ToddleShark, aiming at espionage. This polymorphic malware uses Microsoft binaries for stealth and conducts extensive data theft. It's an evolution of Kimsuky's espionage toolkit, hinting at their refined strategies for long-term intelligence gathering. ToddleShark manipulates registry settings, employs scheduled tasks for persistence, and exfiltrates data using PEM certificates, showcasing advanced obfuscation and evasion techniques. Be vigilant and patch up!

#CyberSecurity #APT #NorthKorea #Malware #ScreenConnect #CVE2024_1708 #CVE2024_1709 #ToddleShark #Kimsuky #DataTheft #Espionage #InfoSec

Source: BleepingComputer.com

Mitre - Kimsuky

##
H3liumb0y at 2024-02-22T08:28:34.111Z ##

"ð¨ Critical Vulnerabilities Alert in ConnectWise Software ð¨"

Two vulnerabilities have been identified in ConnectWise's remote desktop software, ScreenConnect, affecting versions 23.9.7 and prior. The first vulnerability (CVE-2024-1708) is a path-traversal issue allowing potential remote code execution or access to sensitive data, rated with a high severity score of 8.4.

The second (CVE-2024-1709) is an authentication bypass, considered critical with a severity score of 10.0, and is easily exploitable with existing proof-of-concept exploits. ConnectWise has issued updates for cloud-hosted instances, but self-hosted deployments need immediate patching. The exposure is global, with significant concentrations in the United States, and it's expected that cybercriminals and nation-state actors will actively exploit these vulnerabilities.

| ---- | ---- | ---- |
| CVE Number | Description | *CVSS Severity* |
| CVE-2024-1708 | ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by a path-traversal vulnerability, which may allow an attacker the ability to execute remote code or directly impact confidential data or critical systems. | 8.4 High |
| CVE-2024-1709 | ConnectWise ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by an authentication bypass using an alternate path or channel vulnerability, which may allow an attacker direct access to confidential information or critical systems. | 10.0 Critical |

Professionals using ConnectWise must urgently patch their systems to mitigate these vulnerabilities. The discovery underscores the importance of rigorous security practices in protecting IT infrastructures.

ð¡ï¸ð»ð

Tags: #CyberSecurity #VulnerabilityAlert #ConnectWise #CVE2024_1708 #CVE2024_1709 #PatchManagement #ITSecurity #RemoteCodeExecution #PrivilegeEscalation

Source: Unit42 by Palo Alto Networks

##
H3liumb0y@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-05T09:16:48.000Z ##

"ð¨ ScreenConnect Exploits Unleash ToddleShark Malware by Kimsuky ð¨"

Kimsuky, the North Korean APT, leverages vulnerabilities in ScreenConnect (CVE-2024-1708 & CVE-2024-1709) to deploy ToddleShark, aiming at espionage. This polymorphic malware uses Microsoft binaries for stealth and conducts extensive data theft. It's an evolution of Kimsuky's espionage toolkit, hinting at their refined strategies for long-term intelligence gathering. ToddleShark manipulates registry settings, employs scheduled tasks for persistence, and exfiltrates data using PEM certificates, showcasing advanced obfuscation and evasion techniques. Be vigilant and patch up!

#CyberSecurity #APT #NorthKorea #Malware #ScreenConnect #CVE2024_1708 #CVE2024_1709 #ToddleShark #Kimsuky #DataTheft #Espionage #InfoSec

Source: BleepingComputer.com

Mitre - Kimsuky

##
H3liumb0y@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-22T08:28:34.000Z ##

"ð¨ Critical Vulnerabilities Alert in ConnectWise Software ð¨"

Two vulnerabilities have been identified in ConnectWise's remote desktop software, ScreenConnect, affecting versions 23.9.7 and prior. The first vulnerability (CVE-2024-1708) is a path-traversal issue allowing potential remote code execution or access to sensitive data, rated with a high severity score of 8.4.

The second (CVE-2024-1709) is an authentication bypass, considered critical with a severity score of 10.0, and is easily exploitable with existing proof-of-concept exploits. ConnectWise has issued updates for cloud-hosted instances, but self-hosted deployments need immediate patching. The exposure is global, with significant concentrations in the United States, and it's expected that cybercriminals and nation-state actors will actively exploit these vulnerabilities.

| ---- | ---- | ---- |
| CVE Number | Description | *CVSS Severity* |
| CVE-2024-1708 | ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by a path-traversal vulnerability, which may allow an attacker the ability to execute remote code or directly impact confidential data or critical systems. | 8.4 High |
| CVE-2024-1709 | ConnectWise ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by an authentication bypass using an alternate path or channel vulnerability, which may allow an attacker direct access to confidential information or critical systems. | 10.0 Critical |

Professionals using ConnectWise must urgently patch their systems to mitigate these vulnerabilities. The discovery underscores the importance of rigorous security practices in protecting IT infrastructures.

ð¡ï¸ð»ð

Tags: #CyberSecurity #VulnerabilityAlert #ConnectWise #CVE2024_1708 #CVE2024_1709 #PatchManagement #ITSecurity #RemoteCodeExecution #PrivilegeEscalation

Source: Unit42 by Palo Alto Networks

##
simontsui at 2024-02-24T13:46:44.076Z ##

Mandiant updated their remediation and hardening guide for responding to the ConnectWise ScreenConnect vunerabilities CVE-2024-1709 and CVE-2024-1708. This 19 page report contains proactive preparation and hardening actions, containment and initial investigative steps, remediation steps, and additional hardening measures.
ð https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/connectwise-screenconnect-hardening-remediation

#ConnectWise #ScreenConnect #vulnerability #RCE #eitw #activeexploitation #CVE_2024_1709 #CISA #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #IOC #CVE_2024_1708

##
simontsui at 2024-02-23T20:29:34.910Z ##

Huntress covers mass exploitation of ScreenConnect vulnerabilities CVE-2024-1709 (and CVE-2024-1708? maybe) in the wild. This includes everything from additional payloads, additional remote monitoring and management (RMM) tools, to cryptominers and Lockbit (variant) ransomware. IOC provided.
ð https://www.huntress.com/blog/slashandgrab-screen-connect-post-exploitation-in-the-wild-cve-2024-1709-cve-2024-1708

#ConnectWise #ScreenConnect #CVE_2024_1709 #CVE_2024_1708 #threatintel #buhtiRansom #Lockbit #ransomware #AsyncRAT #infostealer #Vidar #Redline #CobaltStrike #Xworm #SimpleHelp #cryptransomware #cybercrime

##
simontsui at 2024-02-23T14:55:59.726Z ##

Sophos covers attacks involving the new ConnectWise ScreenConnect vulnerabilities. This includes a Lockbit ransomware variant (buhtiRansom) using the leaked builder tool in 2023. Other attacks involved dropping AsyncRAT, Rust infostealer, and Vidar/Redline stealer. One attack dropped another remote access client called SimpleHelp, followed up by CRYPT ransomware. There were also Cobalt Strike and Xworm payloads. Sophos provides threat hunting information. No IOC.
ð https://news.sophos.com/en-us/2024/02/23/connectwise-screenconnect-attacks-deliver-malware/

#ConnectWise #ScreenConnect #CVE_2024_1709 #CVE_2024_1708 #threatintel #buhtiRansom #Lockbit #ransomware #AsyncRAT #infostealer #Vidar #Redline #CobaltStrike #Xworm #SimpleHelp #cryptransomware #cybercrime

##
simontsui at 2024-02-22T15:11:19.922Z ##

CISA adds only CVE-2024-1709 (10.0 critical, disclosed 19 February 2024 by ConnectWise) ScreenConnect authentication bypass vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog.
ð https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/02/22/cisa-adds-one-known-exploited-vulnerability-catalog

#ConnectWise #ScreenConnect #vulnerability #RCE #eitw #activeexploitation #CVE_2024_1709 #CISA #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #IOC

##
simontsui at 2024-02-22T01:41:26.523Z ##

Unit 42 posts a late night warning about ConnectWise ScreenConnect Vulnerabilities CVE-2024-1708 and CVE-2024-1709. Waiting out the commotion of the past 12 hours certainly helped. They cover the main talking points of these vulnerabilities' severity, being trivially exploitable, the existence of proofs of concept, active exploitation, and indicators of compromise. Oh and they include CVE IDs, which many publications today did not update their articles with.
ð https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/connectwise-threat-brief-cve-2024-1708-cve-2024-1709/

#ConnectWise #ScreenConnect #vulnerability #RCE #eitw #activeexploitation #CVE_2024_1709 #CISA #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #IOC

##
simontsui at 2024-02-21T17:58:33.517Z ##

CISA will add CVE-2024-1709 (10.0 critical, disclosed 19 February 2024 by ConnectWise) ScreenConnect authentication bypass vulnerability to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog based on evidence of active exploitation.

#ConnectWise #ScreenConnect #vulnerability #RCE #eitw #activeexploitation #CVE_2024_1709 #CISA #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #IOC

CISA assigned CVE-2024-1709 and CVE-2024-1708 to the actively exploited ConnectWise ScreenConnect RCE vulnerabilities:

  • https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2024-1709
  • https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2024-1708

##
H3liumb0y at 2024-03-05T09:16:48.983Z ##

"ð¨ ScreenConnect Exploits Unleash ToddleShark Malware by Kimsuky ð¨"

Kimsuky, the North Korean APT, leverages vulnerabilities in ScreenConnect (CVE-2024-1708 & CVE-2024-1709) to deploy ToddleShark, aiming at espionage. This polymorphic malware uses Microsoft binaries for stealth and conducts extensive data theft. It's an evolution of Kimsuky's espionage toolkit, hinting at their refined strategies for long-term intelligence gathering. ToddleShark manipulates registry settings, employs scheduled tasks for persistence, and exfiltrates data using PEM certificates, showcasing advanced obfuscation and evasion techniques. Be vigilant and patch up!

#CyberSecurity #APT #NorthKorea #Malware #ScreenConnect #CVE2024_1708 #CVE2024_1709 #ToddleShark #Kimsuky #DataTheft #Espionage #InfoSec

Source: BleepingComputer.com

Mitre - Kimsuky

##
H3liumb0y at 2024-02-22T08:28:34.111Z ##

"ð¨ Critical Vulnerabilities Alert in ConnectWise Software ð¨"

Two vulnerabilities have been identified in ConnectWise's remote desktop software, ScreenConnect, affecting versions 23.9.7 and prior. The first vulnerability (CVE-2024-1708) is a path-traversal issue allowing potential remote code execution or access to sensitive data, rated with a high severity score of 8.4.

The second (CVE-2024-1709) is an authentication bypass, considered critical with a severity score of 10.0, and is easily exploitable with existing proof-of-concept exploits. ConnectWise has issued updates for cloud-hosted instances, but self-hosted deployments need immediate patching. The exposure is global, with significant concentrations in the United States, and it's expected that cybercriminals and nation-state actors will actively exploit these vulnerabilities.

| ---- | ---- | ---- |
| CVE Number | Description | *CVSS Severity* |
| CVE-2024-1708 | ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by a path-traversal vulnerability, which may allow an attacker the ability to execute remote code or directly impact confidential data or critical systems. | 8.4 High |
| CVE-2024-1709 | ConnectWise ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by an authentication bypass using an alternate path or channel vulnerability, which may allow an attacker direct access to confidential information or critical systems. | 10.0 Critical |

Professionals using ConnectWise must urgently patch their systems to mitigate these vulnerabilities. The discovery underscores the importance of rigorous security practices in protecting IT infrastructures.

ð¡ï¸ð»ð

Tags: #CyberSecurity #VulnerabilityAlert #ConnectWise #CVE2024_1708 #CVE2024_1709 #PatchManagement #ITSecurity #RemoteCodeExecution #PrivilegeEscalation

Source: Unit42 by Palo Alto Networks

##
H3liumb0y@infosec.exchange at 2024-03-05T09:16:48.000Z ##

"ð¨ ScreenConnect Exploits Unleash ToddleShark Malware by Kimsuky ð¨"

Kimsuky, the North Korean APT, leverages vulnerabilities in ScreenConnect (CVE-2024-1708 & CVE-2024-1709) to deploy ToddleShark, aiming at espionage. This polymorphic malware uses Microsoft binaries for stealth and conducts extensive data theft. It's an evolution of Kimsuky's espionage toolkit, hinting at their refined strategies for long-term intelligence gathering. ToddleShark manipulates registry settings, employs scheduled tasks for persistence, and exfiltrates data using PEM certificates, showcasing advanced obfuscation and evasion techniques. Be vigilant and patch up!

#CyberSecurity #APT #NorthKorea #Malware #ScreenConnect #CVE2024_1708 #CVE2024_1709 #ToddleShark #Kimsuky #DataTheft #Espionage #InfoSec

Source: BleepingComputer.com

Mitre - Kimsuky

##
H3liumb0y@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-22T08:28:34.000Z ##

"ð¨ Critical Vulnerabilities Alert in ConnectWise Software ð¨"

Two vulnerabilities have been identified in ConnectWise's remote desktop software, ScreenConnect, affecting versions 23.9.7 and prior. The first vulnerability (CVE-2024-1708) is a path-traversal issue allowing potential remote code execution or access to sensitive data, rated with a high severity score of 8.4.

The second (CVE-2024-1709) is an authentication bypass, considered critical with a severity score of 10.0, and is easily exploitable with existing proof-of-concept exploits. ConnectWise has issued updates for cloud-hosted instances, but self-hosted deployments need immediate patching. The exposure is global, with significant concentrations in the United States, and it's expected that cybercriminals and nation-state actors will actively exploit these vulnerabilities.

| ---- | ---- | ---- |
| CVE Number | Description | *CVSS Severity* |
| CVE-2024-1708 | ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by a path-traversal vulnerability, which may allow an attacker the ability to execute remote code or directly impact confidential data or critical systems. | 8.4 High |
| CVE-2024-1709 | ConnectWise ScreenConnect 23.9.7 and prior are affected by an authentication bypass using an alternate path or channel vulnerability, which may allow an attacker direct access to confidential information or critical systems. | 10.0 Critical |

Professionals using ConnectWise must urgently patch their systems to mitigate these vulnerabilities. The discovery underscores the importance of rigorous security practices in protecting IT infrastructures.

oversecurity@mastodon.social at 2024-03-05T14:50:05.000Z ##

ScreenConnect flaws exploited to drop new ToddlerShark malware

The North Korean APT hacking group Kimsuky is exploiting ScreenConnect flaws, particularly CVE-2024-1708 and CVE-2024-1709, to infect targets with...

ðï¸ [Bleepingcomputer] https://link.is.it/0uzqqw

##

##
pentesttools at 2024-02-28T12:55:44.075Z ##

ð¨ Just launched: FREE scanner for #SlashAndGrab ð¥·, the ConnectWise ScreenConnect vulnerabilities: https://pentest-tools.com/network-vulnerability-scanning/connectwise-screenconnect-cve-2024-1709-vulnerability-scanner

ð Here are the specs:

When John Hammond started posting about CVE-2024-1709 (CVSSv3 10) & CVE-2024-1708 (CVSSv3 8.4), we instantly picked up on them.

Our team moved fast and added detection for both CVEs, knowing attackers are actively trying to use them (CVE-2024-1709 especially) to bypass security controls and gain unrestricted system access.

We also turned it into a FREE tool for any pentester to use: https://pentest-tools.com/network-vulnerability-scanning/connectwise-screenconnect-cve-2024-1709-vulnerability-scanner

##
todb at 2024-02-28T03:12:55.239Z ##

@austinlarsen @simontsui nbd, you're not the only one.

I'm still on the (now somewhat passive) hunt for any real evidence of exploitation for the other one. Lots of conjecture, loads of hits for CVE-2024-1709, but nothing solid for CVE-2024-1708. Every news outlet seems to just conflate the two and sometimes gets them backwards.

##
simontsui at 2024-02-27T12:45:28.527Z ##

@campuscodi one question I have is, do they even need to exploit CVE-2024-1708? With CVE-2024-1709, they create an admin user on the ScreenConnect server, giving them full control. This is a one character cheat, whereas 1708 requires user interaction and privileges (CVSS:3.1/AV:N/AC:L/PR:H/UI:R/S:C/C:H/I:H/A:H)

I don't specifically see it in the Trend Micro article, but is there actual evidence of CVE-2024-1708 exploitation? Since unpatched versions of ScreenConnect are vulnerable to both 1708 and 1709, it's almost certainly going to make 1709 the more valuable exploit.

##
campuscodi@mastodon.social at 2024-02-27T12:34:44.000Z ##

Trend Micro says the BlackBasta and the Bl00dy ransomware gangs are now exploiting two recently disclosed ScreenConnect vulnerabilities (CVE-2024-1708 and CVE-2024-1709) to breach networks and encrypt files.

https://www.trendmicro.com/en_us/research/24/b/threat-actor-groups-including-black-basta-are-exploiting-recent-.html

simontsui at 2024-02-22T16:53:17.102Z ##

@todb ConnectWise's security advisory lacks definitive verbiage that shows which vulnerability was exploited. Based on their language, and with no clear delineation, I was led to believe that both vulnerabilities were exploited.

However, given how trivial CVE-2024-1709 is /, there'd be no point in exploiting 1708.

##
simontsui at 2024-02-21T20:11:02.709Z ##

@rallias @mttaggart likely referring to ConnectWise ScreenConnect remote code execution vulnerabilities. They were disclosed without CVE IDs on 19 February 2024.

According to CVE.org records, Cybersecurity And Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) U.S. Civilian Government assigned CVE-2024-1708 (8.4 high) to the path traversal vulnerability and CVE-2024-1709 (10.0 critical) to the authentication bypass vulnerability.

  • Security advisory: https://www.connectwise.com/company/trust/security-bulletins/connectwise-screenconnect-23.9.8
  • CVE.org https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2024-1708
  • CVE.org https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2024-1709
  • Technical analyses: https://www.huntress.com/blog/a-catastrophe-for-control-understanding-the-screenconnect-authentication-bypass
  • Proof of Concept: https://github.com/watchtowrlabs/connectwise-screenconnect_auth-bypass-add-user-poc
  • Proof of Concept 2: https://www.horizon3.ai/attack-research/red-team/connectwise-screenconnect-auth-bypass-deep-dive/

pentesttools@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-28T12:55:44.000Z ##

ð¨ Just launched: FREE scanner for #SlashAndGrab ð¥·, the ConnectWise ScreenConnect vulnerabilities: https://pentest-tools.com/network-vulnerability-scanning/connectwise-screenconnect-cve-2024-1709-vulnerability-scanner

ð Here are the specs:

When John Hammond started posting about CVE-2024-1709 (CVSSv3 10) & CVE-2024-1708 (CVSSv3 8.4), we instantly picked up on them.

Our team moved fast and added detection for both CVEs, knowing attackers are actively trying to use them (CVE-2024-1709 especially) to bypass security controls and gain unrestricted system access.

We also turned it into a FREE tool for any pentester to use: https://pentest-tools.com/network-vulnerability-scanning/connectwise-screenconnect-cve-2024-1709-vulnerability-scanner

simontsui at 2024-02-27T17:55:58.590Z ##

@campuscodi Important to note that APT28 exploited CVE-2023-23397 as a zero-day since early 2022.

CVE-2023-23397 is a Microsoft Outlook Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability (9.8 critical, disclosed 14 March 2023 on Patch Tuesday as exploited zero day, added to CISA KEV Catalog same day).

CVE-2024-23897
(7.5 HIGH)

EPSS: 41.54%

updated 2024-02-29T11:15:08.647000

3 posts

Jenkins 2.441 and earlier, LTS 2.426.2 and earlier does not disable a feature of its CLI command parser that replaces an '@' character followed by a file path in an argument with the file's contents, allowing unauthenticated attackers to read arbitrary files on the Jenkins controller file system.

simontsui at 2024-02-27T15:35:00.614Z ##

Analyst comment: It's a little concerning how there's no reporting of active exploitation of CVE-2024-23897 (7.5 high, disclosed 24 January 2024 by Jenkins) an arbitrary file read vulnerability leading to remote code execution. It already has multiple proofs of concept. And yet the only report was a single exploitation in a honeypot capture by a university graduate student, which everyone repeated ad nauseam: https://infosec.exchange/@simontsui/111835020715820485

CVE-2024-22320
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 38.32%

updated 2024-02-02T03:30:43

1 posts

IBM Operational Decision Manager 8.10.3, 8.10.4, 8.10.5.1, 8.11, 8.11.0.1, and 8.12.0.1 could allow a remote authenticated attacker to execute arbitrary code on the system, caused by an unsafe deserialization. By sending specially crafted request, an attacker could exploit this vulnerability to execute arbitrary code in the context of SYSTEM. IBM X-Force ID: 279146.

Nuclei template

simontsui at 2024-02-22T12:44:26.957Z ##

JNDI injection to RCE) . It's worth noting that NVD assigned different scores that align with the impact. Humorous article that is Street Fighter-themed.

##

CVE-2024-22319
(8.1 HIGH)

EPSS: 23.23%

updated 2024-02-06T21:30:25

1 posts

IBM Operational Decision Manager 8.10.3, 8.10.4, 8.10.5.1, 8.11, 8.11.0.1, and 8.12.0.1 could allow a remote attacker to conduct an LDAP injection. By sending a request with a specially crafted request, an attacker could exploit this vulnerability to inject unsanitized content into the LDAP filter. IBM X-Force ID: 279145.

Nuclei template

simontsui at 2024-02-22T12:44:26.957Z ##

JNDI injection to RCE) . It's worth noting that NVD assigned different scores that align with the impact. Humorous article that is Street Fighter-themed.

CVE-2023-6448
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 6.84%

updated 2023-12-19T15:30:29

1 posts

Unitronics Vision Series PLCs and HMIs use default administrative passwords. An unauthenticated attacker with network access to a PLC or HMI can take administrative control of the system.

simontsui at 2024-02-27T18:49:09.054Z ##

@mttaggart remember that time the civilian government agency CISA assigned a CVE ID for a default password vulnerability (CVE-2023-6448 for reference) and put it into the KEV Catalog? #CVECrowdDeny

##

CVE-2024-21626
(8.6 HIGH)

EPSS: 5.06%

updated 2024-02-20T19:26:11

4 posts

### Impact In runc 1.1.11 and earlier, due to an internal file descriptor leak, an attacker could cause a newly-spawned container process (from `runc exec`) to have a working directory in the host filesystem namespace, allowing for a container escape by giving access to the host filesystem ("attack 2"). The same attack could be used by a malicious image to allow a container process to gain access

https://github.com/cdxiaodong/CVE-2024-21626

simontsui at 2024-02-28T23:00:36.861Z ##

unexpected Microsoft Security Response Center (MSRC) security advisory: GitHub: CVE-2024-21626 (8.6 high, known as #LeakyVessels) Container breakout through process.cwd trickery and leaked fds. "CVE-2024-21626 involves a file descriptor leak in runc, potentially enabling attackers to access the host system."

##

CVE-2023-50387
(7.5 HIGH)

EPSS: 3.66%

updated 2024-02-29T03:33:05

1 posts

Certain DNSSEC aspects of the DNS protocol (in RFC 4035 and related RFCs) allow remote attackers to cause a denial of service (CPU consumption) via one or more DNSSEC responses when there is a zone with many DNSKEY and RRSIG records, aka the "KeyTrap" issue. The protocol specification implies that an algorithm must evaluate all combinations of DNSKEY and RRSIG records.

1 repos

https://github.com/knqyf263/CVE-2023-50387

kurtseifried at 2024-02-24T23:32:28.466Z ##

With respect to the dns bind flaw CVE-2023-50387

âWith these changes, a DNSSEC validation attack which bypasses all other limits will be able to consume no more than approximately 1/2 of CPU capacity on the affected machine, leaving the other half for normal processing.â

Likeâ¦ I guess this is better than the attacker using all of the CPUâ¦

##

CVE-2024-21410
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 2.32%

updated 2024-02-13T18:38:31

3 posts

Microsoft Exchange Server Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability

1 repos

https://github.com/FreakyM0ndy/CVE-2024-21410-poc

simontsui at 2024-03-05T00:07:57.678Z ##

Increased scrutiny on Microsoft as @dangoodin writes for Ars Technica: Hackers exploited Windows 0-day for 6 months after Microsoft knew of it. Microsoft only announced two exploited zero-days during their February 2024 Patch Tuesday, but botched an update to a third exploited zero-day CVE-2024-21410 (accidentally updating CVE-2024-21413 instead). Now, Avast claimed that CVE-2024-21338 was exploited in the wild since at least August 2023 (date that they notified Microsoft with a PoC).

#CISA #KEV #CVE_2024_21338 #vulnerability #IOCTL #EoP #Avast #eitw #activeexploitation #MSRC #Microsoft

##

CVE-2020-3259
(7.5 HIGH)

EPSS: 1.93%

updated 2023-08-16T18:30:19

1 posts

A vulnerability in the web services interface of Cisco Adaptive Security Appliance (ASA) Software and Cisco Firepower Threat Defense (FTD) Software could allow an unauthenticated, remote attacker to retrieve memory contents on an affected device, which could lead to the disclosure of confidential information. The vulnerability is due to a buffer tracking issue when the software parses invalid URLs

simontsui at 2024-02-21T16:42:24.739Z ##

TrueSec reported on 29 January 2024 that CVE-2020-3259 was the initial access vector used by the Akira ransomware group: https://www.truesec.com/hub/blog/akira-ransomware-and-exploitation-of-cisco-anyconnect-vulnerability-cve-2020-3259

CISA added CVE-2020-3259 to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog last week on 15 February 2024: https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/02/15/cisa-adds-two-known-exploited-vulnerabilities-catalog

Kudos to Kevin Beaumont @GossiTheDog for pointing it out https://infosec.exchange/@GossiTheDog@cyberplace.social/111848756716864132

and to @greynoise as well https://infosec.exchange/@greynoise/111903424060756186

#Cisco #CVE_2020_3259 #ASA #informationdisclosure #eitw #activeexploitation #vulnerability #CISA #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #Akira #ransomware

CVE-2023-5631
(6.1 MEDIUM)

EPSS: 0.68%

updated 2023-11-17T15:30:26

1 posts

Roundcube before 1.4.15, 1.5.x before 1.5.5, and 1.6.x before 1.6.4 allows stored XSS via an HTML e-mail message with a crafted SVG document because of program/lib/Roundcube/rcube_washtml.php behavior. This could allow a remote attacker to load arbitrary JavaScript code.

CVE-2024-22024
(8.3 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.60%

updated 2024-02-13T15:31:12

8 posts

An XML external entity or XXE vulnerability in the SAML component of Ivanti Connect Secure (9.x, 22.x), Ivanti Policy Secure (9.x, 22.x) and ZTA gateways which allows an attacker to access certain restricted resources without authentication.

2 repos

https://github.com/labesterOct/CVE-2024-22024

https://github.com/0dteam/CVE-2024-22024

simontsui at 2024-03-02T01:23:46.663Z ##

TechCrunch: NSA confirmed that hackers exploiting flaws in Ivantiâs widely used enterprise VPN appliance have targeted organizations across the U.S. defense sector.
ð https://techcrunch.com/2024/03/01/nsa-says-its-tracking-ivanti-cyberattacks-as-hackers-hit-us-defense-sector/

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

##
simontsui at 2024-02-29T18:13:43.608Z ##

Hot off the press! CISA along with FBI, MS-ISAC, Australia ASD ACSC, NCSC-UK, NCSC-NZ, Canadian Centre for Cyber Security and CERT NZ release joint cybersecurity advisory Threat Actors Exploit Multiple Vulnerabilities in Ivanti Connect Secure and Policy Secure Gateways. It includes TTPs, IOCs, and detection methods to help network defenders mitigate risk.
ð https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060b

Of particular concern, the authoring organizations and industry partners have determined that cyber threat actors are able to deceive Ivantiâs internal and external Integrity Checker Tool (ICT), resulting in a failure to detect compromise.

During multiple incident response engagements associated with this activity, CISA identified that Ivantiâs internal and previous external ICT failed to detect compromise. In addition, CISA has conducted independent research in a lab environment validating that the Ivanti ICT is not sufficient to detect compromise and that a cyber threat actor may be able to gain root-level persistence despite issuing factory resets.

The authoring organizations strongly urge all organizations to consider the significant risk of adversary access to, and persistence on, Ivanti Connect Secure and Ivanti Policy Secure gateways when determining whether to continue operating these devices in an enterprise environment.

cc: @campuscodi @briankrebs @deepthoughts10 @serghei @selenalarson @DaveMWilburn

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

##
simontsui at 2024-02-28T21:15:54.019Z ##

This line from Mandiant's article stuck out to me: "In addition, we have seen the threat actor demonstrate a nuanced understanding of the appliance and their ability to subvert detection throughout this campaign."

The reason is because of the following:

The internal ICT is configured to run in two-hour intervals by default and is meant to be run in conjunction with continuous monitoring. Any malicious file system modifications made and reverted between the two-hour scan intervals would remain undetected by the ICT. When the activation and deactivation routines are performed tactfully in quick succession, it can minimize the risk of ICT detection by timing the activation routine to coincide precisely with the intended use of the BUSHWALK webshell.

This sentence also concerns me, giving me flashbacks to Eclypsium's article

An encrypted version of BUSHWALK is placed in a directory excluded by the integrity checker tool (ICT)

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024

##
simontsui at 2024-02-27T19:45:07.447Z ##

Ivanti has a related blog post regarding evolving threat actor tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs). These findings were identified in the ongoing analysis of the previously disclosed vulnerabilities affecting Ivanti Connect Secure, Policy Secure and ZTA gateways, and include potential persistence techniques.
ð https://www.ivanti.com/blog/enhanced-external-integrity-checking-tool-to-provide-additional-visibility-and-protection-for-customers-against-evolving-threat-actor-techniques-in-relation-to-previously-disclosed-vulnerabilities

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_21893 #CVE_2024_22024

Hot off the press! CISA along with FBI, MS-ISAC, Australia ASD ACSC, NCSC-UK, NCSC-NZ, Canadian Centre for Cyber Security and CERT NZ release joint cybersecurity advisory Threat Actors Exploit Multiple Vulnerabilities in Ivanti Connect Secure and Policy Secure Gateways. It includes TTPs, IOCs, and detection methods to help network defenders mitigate risk.
ð https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060b

Of particular concern, the authoring organizations and industry partners have determined that cyber threat actors are able to deceive Ivantiâs internal and external Integrity Checker Tool (ICT), resulting in a failure to detect compromise.

During multiple incident response engagements associated with this activity, CISA identified that Ivantiâs internal and previous external ICT failed to detect compromise. In addition, CISA has conducted independent research in a lab environment validating that the Ivanti ICT is not sufficient to detect compromise and that a cyber threat actor may be able to gain root-level persistence despite issuing factory resets.

The authoring organizations strongly urge all organizations to consider the significant risk of adversary access to, and persistence on, Ivanti Connect Secure and Ivanti Policy Secure gateways when determining whether to continue operating these devices in an enterprise environment.

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-28T21:15:54.000Z ##

This line from Mandiant's article stuck out to me: "In addition, we have seen the threat actor demonstrate a nuanced understanding of the appliance and their ability to subvert detection throughout this campaign."

The reason is because of the following:

The internal ICT is configured to run in two-hour intervals by default and is meant to be run in conjunction with continuous monitoring. Any malicious file system modifications made and reverted between the two-hour scan intervals would remain undetected by the ICT. When the activation and deactivation routines are performed tactfully in quick succession, it can minimize the risk of ICT detection by timing the activation routine to coincide precisely with the intended use of the BUSHWALK webshell.

This sentence also concerns me, giving me flashbacks to Eclypsium's article

An encrypted version of BUSHWALK is placed in a directory excluded by the integrity checker tool (ICT)

simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-27T19:45:07.000Z ##

CVE-2019-8950
(9.8 CRITICAL)

EPSS: 0.20%

updated 2023-02-01T05:06:55

1 posts

ntkramer at 2024-02-23T19:03:59.022Z ##

ð¥ª & #threatintel: Increased interest in CVE-2019-8950, a known backdoor account in certain versions of DASAN H665 (a compact GPON Optical Network Terminal (ONT) for both residential and business customers.)

https://viz.greynoise.io/tags/dasan-h665-backdoor-attempt?days=30

##

CVE-2024-21802
(8.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.09%

updated 2024-02-26T18:30:37

1 posts

A heap-based buffer overflow vulnerability exists in the GGUF library info->ne functionality of llama.cpp Commit 18c2e17. A specially crafted .gguf file can lead to code execution. An attacker can provide a malicious file to trigger this vulnerability.

philippclassen at 2024-03-03T22:48:14.407Z ##

When running local LLMs, some care should be taken when using untrusted models.

An obvious problem exists with models that include unsafe format like "pickle" for serializing their weights (https://jfrog.com/blog/data-scientists-targeted-by-malicious-hugging-face-ml-models-with-silent-backdoor/).

Fortunately, most models now are using safetensors or .gguf, which do not require code execution. However, even with these safe formats, bugs in the inference engines can be exploited.

For instance, llama.cpp recently fixed some overflows that could be exploited by a malicious .gguf to run arbitrary code:
* https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2024-23496
* https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2024-21802
* https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-21836

That is not surprising, but it is a reminder to keep software up-to-date - including inference engines.

When running agents that use generative AI (e.g. via APIs like ChatGPT or Gemini), there are also new attack vectors being found.Recently, the Morris II AI Prompt Worm demonstrates an attack on email assistance agents:

https://sites.google.com/view/compromptmized

#security #llm #ai #llamacpp

##

CVE-2024-21836
(8.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.09%

updated 2024-02-26T18:30:37

1 posts

A heap-based buffer overflow vulnerability exists in the GGUF library header.n_tensors functionality of llama.cpp Commit 18c2e17. A specially crafted .gguf file can lead to code execution. An attacker can provide a malicious file to trigger this vulnerability.

philippclassen at 2024-03-03T22:48:14.407Z ##

When running local LLMs, some care should be taken when using untrusted models.

An obvious problem exists with models that include unsafe format like "pickle" for serializing their weights (https://jfrog.com/blog/data-scientists-targeted-by-malicious-hugging-face-ml-models-with-silent-backdoor/).

Fortunately, most models now are using safetensors or .gguf, which do not require code execution. However, even with these safe formats, bugs in the inference engines can be exploited.

For instance, llama.cpp recently fixed some overflows that could be exploited by a malicious .gguf to run arbitrary code:
* https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2024-23496
* https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2024-21802
* https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-21836

That is not surprising, but it is a reminder to keep software up-to-date - including inference engines.

CVE-2024-23496
(8.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.09%

updated 2024-02-26T18:30:37

1 posts

A heap-based buffer overflow vulnerability exists in the GGUF library gguf_fread_str functionality of llama.cpp Commit 18c2e17. A specially crafted .gguf file can lead to code execution. An attacker can provide a malicious file to trigger this vulnerability.

philippclassen at 2024-03-03T22:48:14.407Z ##

When running local LLMs, some care should be taken when using untrusted models.

An obvious problem exists with models that include unsafe format like "pickle" for serializing their weights (https://jfrog.com/blog/data-scientists-targeted-by-malicious-hugging-face-ml-models-with-silent-backdoor/).

Fortunately, most models now are using safetensors or .gguf, which do not require code execution. However, even with these safe formats, bugs in the inference engines can be exploited.

For instance, llama.cpp recently fixed some overflows that could be exploited by a malicious .gguf to run arbitrary code:
* https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2024-23496
* https://www.cve.org/CVERecord?id=CVE-2024-21802
* https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2024-21836

That is not surprising, but it is a reminder to keep software up-to-date - including inference engines.

When running agents that use generative AI (e.g. via APIs like ChatGPT or Gemini), there are also new attack vectors being found.Recently, the Morris II AI Prompt Worm demonstrates an attack on email assistance agents:

https://sites.google.com/view/compromptmized

CVE-2024-26192
(8.2 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.09%

updated 2024-02-24T00:30:26

2 posts

Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) Information Disclosure Vulnerability

todb at 2024-02-24T14:39:21.859Z ##

@simontsui

CVE-2024-26192 is missing an exploitability assessment

ð

##
simontsui at 2024-02-23T21:52:47.414Z ##

MSRC (Microsoft) released 11 Chromium-related security advisories. The ones not already included in Google's original post are as follows:

  • CVE-2024-21423 (4.8 medium) Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) Information Disclosure Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-26188 (4.3 medium) Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) Spoofing Vulnerability
  • CVE-2024-26192 (8.2 high) Microsoft Edge (Chromium-based) Information Disclosure Vulnerability

The Frequently Asked Questions (FAQ) section of each vulnerability explains a lot more than Google normally would. Also provides a CVSSv3 score. These are noted as Not Publicly Disclosed, Not Exploited, and Exploitation Less Likely (CVE-2024-26192 is missing an exploitability assessment).

#Microsoft #MSRC #securityadvisory #vulnerability #Chrome #Chromium

##

CVE-2023-52160(CVSS UNKNOWN)

EPSS: 0.08%

updated 2024-02-27T18:31:01

2 posts

The implementation of PEAP in wpa_supplicant through 2.10 allows authentication bypass. For a successful attack, wpa_supplicant must be configured to not verify the network's TLS certificate during Phase 1 authentication, and an eap_peap_decrypt vulnerability can then be abused to skip Phase 2 authentication. The attack vector is sending an EAP-TLV Success packet instead of starting Phase 2. This

1 repos

https://github.com/Helica-core/eap_pwn

jbhall56 at 2024-02-22T13:25:04.195Z ##

The vulnerabilities, tracked as CVE-2023-52160 and CVE-2023-52161, have been discovered following a security evaluation of wpa_supplicant and Intel's iNet Wireless Daemon (IWD), respectively. https://thehackernews.com/2024/02/new-wi-fi-vulnerabilities-expose.html

##
dominee at 2024-02-22T08:47:01.003Z ##

##
jos1264@social.skynetcloud.site at 2024-02-29T12:45:02.000Z ##

Windows Zero-Day Exploited by North Korean Hackers in Rootkit Attack https://www.securityweek.com/windows-zero-day-exploited-by-north-korean-hackers-in-rootkit-attack/ #Malware&Threats #Vulnerabilities #CVE202421338 #NorthKorea #exploited #Featured #Lazarus #Windows #ZeroDay

##
simontsui at 2024-03-05T00:07:57.678Z ##

Increased scrutiny on Microsoft as @dangoodin writes for Ars Technica: Hackers exploited Windows 0-day for 6 months after Microsoft knew of it. Microsoft only announced two exploited zero-days during their February 2024 Patch Tuesday, but botched an update to a third exploited zero-day CVE-2024-21410 (accidentally updating CVE-2024-21413 instead). Now, Avast claimed that CVE-2024-21338 was exploited in the wild since at least August 2023 (date that they notified Microsoft with a PoC).

#CISA #KEV #CVE_2024_21338 #vulnerability #IOCTL #EoP #Avast #eitw #activeexploitation #MSRC #Microsoft

##
simontsui at 2024-03-04T21:04:57.969Z ##

Microsoft Security Response Center (MSRC) quietly updated its security advisory for CVE-2024-21338 following the Avast blog post on 28 February 2024 claiming zero-day exploitation. Version 1.2 for Feb 28, 2024 reads "Updated the Exploitability Index to 0 - Exploitation Detected and Exploited to Yes. This is an informational change only."

Analyst Note: This quiet update did not occur on 28 February as suggested, as multiple people in the infosec community were checking it, and the RSS feed for it did not get updated. This puts the total number of exploited zero-days in February 2024 up to FOUR.
ð https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2024-21338

cc: @todb

#CISA #KEV #CVE_2024_21338 #vulnerability #IOCTL #EoP #Avast #eitw #activeexploitation #MSRC #Microsoft

##
simontsui at 2024-03-04T16:07:55.931Z ##

CISA adds CVE-2024-21338 (7.8 high) to the Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) Catalog. This was reported by Avast researchers to be exploited by North Korean APT Lazarus Group previously as a zero-day in the wild.
ð https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/alerts/2024/03/04/cisa-adds-one-known-exploited-vulnerability-catalog

#CISA #KEV #CVE_2024_21338 #vulnerability #IOCTL #EoP #Avast #eitw #activeexploitation

##
simontsui at 2024-02-28T13:39:35.309Z ##

Avast reports that the North Korean state-sponsored APT Lazarus Group exploited CVE-2024-21338 (7.8 high, disclosed 13 February 2024 by Microsoft) Windows Kernel Elevation of Privilege Vulnerability previously as a zero-day. Avast doesn't provide a timeline, but states that they recreated Proof of Concept and submitted it in August 2023.
ð https://decoded.avast.io/janvojtesek/lazarus-and-the-fudmodule-rootkit-beyond-byovd-with-an-admin-to-kernel-zero-day/

cc: @campuscodi

simontsui at 2024-02-28T19:27:47.904Z ##

Yeah I had issues with how Avast keeps calling it a zero-day but there's no timeline available, and that Microsoft does not list it as Exploited.

"We developed a custom PoC (Proof of Concept) exploit and submitted it in August 2023 as part of a vulnerability report to Microsoft, leading to an advisory for CVE-2024-21338 in the February Patch Tuesday update."

They sat on what they call an ITW 0-day for at least 6 months if we take that quote at face value.

##

CVE-2023-52161(CVSS UNKNOWN)

EPSS: 0.06%

updated 2024-02-22T18:30:29

3 posts

The Access Point functionality in eapol_auth_key_handle in eapol.c in iNet wireless daemon (IWD) before 2.14 allows attackers to gain unauthorized access to a protected Wi-Fi network. An attacker can complete the EAPOL handshake by skipping Msg2/4 and instead sending Msg4/4 with an all-zero key.

alexrad at 2024-02-26T22:10:47.019Z ##

CVE-2023-52161: inet-wireless daemon (iwd) APs allowed clients to connect with a NULL key, bypassing the WiFi password

https://www.top10vpn.com/research/wifi-vulnerabilities/

##
todb at 2024-02-25T14:35:49.960Z ##

@patrickcmiller

CVE-2023-52161, in particular, permits an adversary to gain unauthorized access to a protected Wi-Fi network, exposing existing users and devices to [â¦] business email compromise (BEC)

How do you get from âoops on the wrong wifi networkâ to âoops I just wired money overseas?â

I suppose I could read the CVE but the attacker value as a BEC vector seems pretty dubious.

CVE-2024-0692
(8.8 HIGH)

updated 2024-03-01T09:31:14

10 posts

The SolarWinds Security Event Manager was susceptible to Remote Code Execution Vulnerability. This vulnerability allows an unauthenticated user to abuse SolarWindsâ service, resulting in remote code execution.

simontsui at 2024-03-05T12:41:13.844Z ##

The individual landing page for SolarWinds' CVE-2024-0692 (8.8 high, disclosed 01 March 2024 by Zero Day Initiative), Deserialization of Untrusted Data Remote Code Execution Vulnerability came out. I'm glad that I rely on other methods instead of just RSS, because the SolarWinds RSS updated 4 days later.
ð https://www.solarwinds.com/trust-center/security-advisories/cve-2024-0692

#SolarWInds #SecurityEventManager #CVE_2024_0692 #vulnerability #ZDI

##
kpwn at 2024-03-03T20:47:54.044Z ##

Nothing to see here. Just a small test in Prod :P

#CVE_2024_0692

##
simontsui at 2024-03-01T21:54:16.423Z ##

An anonymous researcher submitted CVE-2024-0692 through Zero Day Initiative. While ZDI marked it as 9.8 critical severity (AV:N/AC:L/PR:N/UI:N/S:U/C:H/I:H/A:H), SolarWinds considers Attack Vector to be Adjacent (AV:A), which reduced the CVSSv3 score to 8.8. Unfortunately, NVD trusts SolarWinds and will likely not audit it. Still an RCE worth 9.8 to me.
ð https://www.zerodayinitiative.com/advisories/ZDI-24-215/

#SolarWInds #SecurityEventManager #CVE_2024_0692 #vulnerability #ZDI

##
simontsui at 2024-03-01T21:40:04.267Z ##

SolarWinds security advisory for Security Event Manager: CVE-2024-0692 (8.8 high) Deserialization of Untrusted Data Remote Code Execution Vulnerability. There are 4 third party introduced vlunerabilities too. No mention of exploitation.
ð https://documentation.solarwinds.com/en/success_center/sem/content/release_notes/sem_2023-4-1_release_notes.htm

##

CVE-2024-21888
(8.8 HIGH)

EPSS: 0.05%

updated 2024-01-31T18:31:27

10 posts

A privilege escalation vulnerability in web component of Ivanti Connect Secure (9.x, 22.x) and Ivanti Policy Secure (9.x, 22.x) allows a user to elevate privileges to that of an administrator.

simontsui at 2024-03-02T01:23:46.663Z ##

TechCrunch: NSA confirmed that hackers exploiting flaws in Ivantiâs widely used enterprise VPN appliance have targeted organizations across the U.S. defense sector.
ð https://techcrunch.com/2024/03/01/nsa-says-its-tracking-ivanti-cyberattacks-as-hackers-hit-us-defense-sector/

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

##
simontsui at 2024-02-29T18:13:43.608Z ##

Hot off the press! CISA along with FBI, MS-ISAC, Australia ASD ACSC, NCSC-UK, NCSC-NZ, Canadian Centre for Cyber Security and CERT NZ release joint cybersecurity advisory Threat Actors Exploit Multiple Vulnerabilities in Ivanti Connect Secure and Policy Secure Gateways. It includes TTPs, IOCs, and detection methods to help network defenders mitigate risk.
ð https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060b

Of particular concern, the authoring organizations and industry partners have determined that cyber threat actors are able to deceive Ivantiâs internal and external Integrity Checker Tool (ICT), resulting in a failure to detect compromise.

During multiple incident response engagements associated with this activity, CISA identified that Ivantiâs internal and previous external ICT failed to detect compromise. In addition, CISA has conducted independent research in a lab environment validating that the Ivanti ICT is not sufficient to detect compromise and that a cyber threat actor may be able to gain root-level persistence despite issuing factory resets.

The authoring organizations strongly urge all organizations to consider the significant risk of adversary access to, and persistence on, Ivanti Connect Secure and Ivanti Policy Secure gateways when determining whether to continue operating these devices in an enterprise environment.

cc: @campuscodi @briankrebs @deepthoughts10 @serghei @selenalarson @DaveMWilburn

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024 #CISA #securityadvisory

##
simontsui at 2024-02-28T21:15:54.019Z ##

This line from Mandiant's article stuck out to me: "In addition, we have seen the threat actor demonstrate a nuanced understanding of the appliance and their ability to subvert detection throughout this campaign."

The reason is because of the following:

The internal ICT is configured to run in two-hour intervals by default and is meant to be run in conjunction with continuous monitoring. Any malicious file system modifications made and reverted between the two-hour scan intervals would remain undetected by the ICT. When the activation and deactivation routines are performed tactfully in quick succession, it can minimize the risk of ICT detection by timing the activation routine to coincide precisely with the intended use of the BUSHWALK webshell.

This sentence also concerns me, giving me flashbacks to Eclypsium's article

An encrypted version of BUSHWALK is placed in a directory excluded by the integrity checker tool (ICT)

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_22024

##
simontsui at 2024-02-27T19:45:07.447Z ##

Ivanti has a related blog post regarding evolving threat actor tactics, techniques and procedures (TTPs). These findings were identified in the ongoing analysis of the previously disclosed vulnerabilities affecting Ivanti Connect Secure, Policy Secure and ZTA gateways, and include potential persistence techniques.
ð https://www.ivanti.com/blog/enhanced-external-integrity-checking-tool-to-provide-additional-visibility-and-protection-for-customers-against-evolving-threat-actor-techniques-in-relation-to-previously-disclosed-vulnerabilities

#cyberespionage #IOC #TTPs #UNC5325 #China #Ivanti #ConnectSecure #vulnerability #zeroday #eitw #activeexploitation #UTA0178 #UNC5221 #CVE_2023_46805 #CVE_2024_21887 #KEV #KnownExploitedVulnerabilitiesCatalog #CISA #CVE_2024_21888 #CVE_2024_21893 #CVE_2024_22024

ð https://www.mandiant.com/resources/blog/investigating-ivanti-exploitation-persistence

cc: @campuscodi @iagox86 @brett

##
simontsui@infosec.exchange at 2024-02-29T18:13:43.000Z ##

Hot off the press! CISA along with FBI, MS-ISAC, Australia ASD ACSC, NCSC-UK, NCSC-NZ, Canadian Centre for Cyber Security and CERT NZ release joint cybersecurity advisory Threat Actors Exploit Multiple Vulnerabilities in Ivanti Connect Secure and Policy Secure Gateways. It includes TTPs, IOCs, and detection methods to help network defenders mitigate risk.
ð https://www.cisa.gov/news-events/cybersecurity-advisories/aa24-060b

Of particular concern, the authoring organizations and industry partners have determined that cyber threat actors are able to deceive Ivantiâs internal and external Integrity Checker Tool (ICT), resulting in a failure to detect compromise.

During multiple incident response engagements associated with this activity, CISA identified that Ivantiâs internal and previous external ICT failed to detect compromise. In addition, CISA has conducted independent research in a lab environment validating that the Ivanti ICT is not sufficient to detect compromise and that a cyber threat actor may be able to gain root-level persistence despite issuing factory resets.

The authoring organizations strongly urge all organizations to consider the significant risk of adversary access to, and persistence on, Ivanti Connect Secure and Ivanti Policy Secure gateways when determining whether to continue operating these devices in an enterprise environment.

This line from Mandiant's article stuck out to me: "In addition, we have seen the threat actor demonstrate a nuanced understanding of the appliance and their ability to subvert detection throughout this campaign."

The reason is because of the following:

The internal ICT is configured to run in two-hour intervals by default and is meant to be run in conjunction with continuous monitoring. Any malicious file system modifications made and reverted between the two-hour scan intervals would remain undetected by the ICT. When the activation and deactivation routines are performed tactfully in quick succession, it can minimize the risk of ICT detection by timing the activation routine to coincide precisely with the intended use of the BUSHWALK webshell.
